author: Chris Herhalt, CP24.com
title: What to know about Toronto FC’s first-ever MLS playoff qualification
text:
In case you were distracted by the Toronto Blue Jays’ raucous, euphoria-inducing Game 5 victory against the Texas Rangers last night, you might want to know that another Toronto sports team, Toronto FC, secured its first ever berth in the Major League Soccer playoffs Thursday night, with a 2-1 win over the New York Red Bulls.
With two games left in the regular season, Toronto FC is second in the MLS’ 10-team Eastern Conference, with the team scheduled to face the Columbus Crew on Oct. 17 and Montreal Impact on Oct. 25.
Playoff structure:
Should TFC remain in second place or higher at the end of the regular season*, they will get a bye to the conference semifinals, with games scheduled for Nov. 1 and Nov. 8. The team that placed first in the conference during the regular season will play the lowest-ranked team remaining after the first playoff round, while the team that placed first in the conference during the regular season will host the second-lowest ranked team that remains after the first playoff round.
The conference semifinal is played using an aggregate score, meaning the team who scores the most goals over both games goes through to the conference final.
The conference final matches are scheduled for Nov. 22 and Nov. 29. They are also played as an aggregate—with the team scoring the most goals over both games combined moving forward.
The final, to decide the winner of the MLS Cup, will be held on Dec. 6, with the highest-ranked team remaining from the regular season awarded home field advantage.
Tickets:
Current season and partial season ticket holders and those seeking season tickets for the 2016 season will have first crack at tickets for the playoffs. Those who sign up at the Toronto FC website as “Insiders” will have the opportunity to buy tickets starting on Oct. 21, and tickets will go on sale for the general public on Oct. 22.
Players to watch:
Sebastian Giovinco: Also known as the “Atomic Ant” for his speed, power and small stature, the Italian national team member scored 22 goals and notched 12 assists for Toronto FC so far this season, also racking up several hat tricks. He came to Toronto FC from Italian giants Juventus F.C. at the start of this season, and earns $7 million USD per year, making him the highest paid player in Major League Soccer, and the highest paid Italian soccer player in the world.
Michael Bradley: As captain of Toronto FC and the U.S. men’s national team, this 28-year-old midfielder scored five goals and earned three assists for the club so far this season. Bradley is described as an attacking midfielder, adept at distributing the ball but also tracking back to help defenders in need.
Jozy Altidore: Dogged by injury, this forward also plays for the U.S. men’s national team and has scored 12 goals in 24 games for Toronto FC so far this season. He’s played in the Dutch, Spanish and English premier leagues, and remains the only American to score goals for his country in five games in a row.
*If Toronto FC finishes the regular season third in its conference or lower, they will play a one-game playoff against another team in the conference on either Oct. 28 or Oct. 29.
